definition:
A dynamic stream can represent an information flow — a sequence of
messages encoded by the sender and communicated using a transmission
channel possibly distorted with noise, to a receiver whose goal is to
reconstruct the sender’s messages and interpret message semantics. —
From: “SHANNON, C. E. 1948. A mathematical theory of communication. Bell
Syst. Tech. J. 27, 379–423, 623–656.”
